item.title: PostgreSQL: 3 Things to Know About UPDATE Statements
item.description: I recently finished reading PostgreSQL 14 Internals by Egor Rogov. This book might be the best PostgreSQL resource besides the official documentation. I consider it one of the rare books that teach applied computer science without watering down the difficult parts. One particularly interesting topic is PostgreSQL’s execution of UPDATE statements. Updates in relational databases are naturally complex. They can be affected by conflicts, anomalies, and deadlocks. However, some behavior is specific to PostgreSQL.

item.title: Professionalism in Software Engineering
item.description: Having worked as a software engineer for a few years, it turns out software engineering is a profession like many others: you are part of a team with fellow humans, and working to achieve something in a collaborative fashion. I find it important that we enjoy working with each other. I would like to be a reliable, cooperative, and helpful coworker. In short, I would like to be a professional (but never boring) version of myself.

item.title: I Actually Like Slack
item.description: As a software engineer, you really need your focus time. Unfortunately, distractions are everywhere! It might be snowing outside, or you might be wondering if now is the perfect time to get a coffee. Then it happensâ€”someone has used Slack’s @channel tag to completely interrupt everybody else, including you. This scenario may sound familiar. The reason is that Slack has given the nuclear codes to everyone in the company, allowing them to destroy productivity with one single command.
